exercise.description:
1. Stand with a shoulder-width stance.
2. Grab the dumbbells with your palms facing each other.
3. Bending your knees slightly, and your core tight, bend over at the waist keeping your lower back tight.
4. Bending over until your upper body is at a 45-degree bend or lower, pull the dumbbells up towards your lower chest, on the side.
5. Keep your elbows as close to your sides as possible.
6. At the top of the movement, you should feel like you are pinching your shoulder blades towards each other.
7. Pause, and return the dumbbells to your starting position.

1. Lean forward into a bench on one knee. 
2. Using a neutral grip, hold a dumbbell in one hand so your palm is facing inward. 
3. Your arm should be fully extended and hanging straight down. 
4. This is the start position. 
5. Pull the dumbbell off the floor towards your hip, flexing your elbow and retracting your shoulder blade. 
6. Return to the start position. 
7. Control the weight down, don’t let the dumbbell fall down with gravity.

1. Grab a pullup bar with an overhand grip, placing your hands wider than shoulder-width apart.
2. Lift your feet off the floor — or place them in the assist band — and hang from your arms.
3. Pull your body up to the bar by bending your arms and pulling your shoulder blades toward the floor.
4. Once your chin crosses the bar, lower your body back down.
5. Complete 1–3 sets of 8–12 reps.

1. Holding a dumbbell in each hand, hinge forward at your hips until your torso forms a 45-degree angle with the floor, allowing the dumbbells to hang in front of you, palms facing each other. Have a slight bend in your elbows. 
2. Engaging your core, lift your arms up and out, squeezing your shoulder blades at the top.
3. Slowly return to the starting position. Complete 1–3 sets of 8–12 reps.

1. Position yourself on a bench so your left knee and shin are resting on it, as well as your left hand — this will be your support. Your right leg should be straight with your foot on the floor. Pick up a dumbbell with your right hand. Maintain a straight torso.
2. Pull the dumbbell up, aiming your elbow toward the sky while keeping it close to your body. Squeeze your upper back as you bend your elbow.
3. Slowly lower back down to the starting position. Complete 1–3 sets of 8–12 reps on each side.

1. Lying on a flat bench place your hands up on the bar griping it slightly wider than shoulder width apart. 
2. Place your feet on the ground in line with or behind your knees. 
3. Create an arch in your lower back and push your chest up. 
4. Lift the bar up off the rack so that the bar is above your chest. 
5. Lower the bar directly down to the chest with your elbow pointing at approximately 45 degrees. 
5. Once the bar touches the chest, pause, and then press directly up again. 
6. Continue until all reps are completed and then re-rack the barbell.

1. Standing between the bars of a dip station, grip the bars with your palms facing inwards, keeping your elbows tucked in close to your body. 
2. Allow your body weight to hang so it is being supported by your arms and shoulders. 
3. Keep your hips straight. Lower your body by slowly bending your elbows and leaning slightly forward and continue down until you feel a stretch in your chest, shoulders and triceps. 
3. Your elbow joint should be at approximately 90 degrees at the bottom of the movement.

1. Lie on your back on a flat bench with your feet firmly on the floor and your arms extended over your chest, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Turn your hands in so your palms are facing, to “crush” the dumbbells up against each other.
2. Pushing the dumbbells together, slowly bend your arms to lower the dumbbells down just to the middle of your chest.
3. Extend your arms straight up and over your chest again, pressing back up to the starting position. Pause briefly at the top before repeating for 8-12 reps.

1. Sit on the chest press seat with your upper chest just above the horizontal handles. 
2. Make sure your feet are flat on the floor. 
3. Grasp the handles using a wide overhand grip and place your elbows out to the sides just below your shoulders. 
4. Push the levers out until your arms are fully extended. 
5. Lower the weight until your hands are at chest level.

1. Sit on a chest fly machine with your back flat against the back rest and your feet on the floor. 
2. Grip the handles and make sure your arms are parallel to the floor. 
3. If not parallel, adjust the seat or handles accordingly. 
4. Exhale and slowly push the handles together squeezing your chest to the middle as you do so. 
5. Hold for a count of one amd return to the starting position.

1. Hold on to a chin up bar with an overhand grip with your legs straight. 
2. Brace your core. 
3. Bend your knees and raise your knees up to chest height and return to the starting position.
4. Avoid swinging your body.

1. Lying on your back with either your arms by your side or hands under your glutes. 
2. Place your knees and feet together. 
3. Brace your Abs and raise your knees up to your chest. 
4. Extend your legs as low as you can without touching the floor and repeat.

1. Sitting on a bench with your legs over the end. 
2. Hold onto either side of the bench. 
3. With your back straight, brace your Abs bring your knees up to your chest then extend your legs out as far as you can.

1. Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet raised off the floor. 
2. Brace your core. 
3. Hold a weight plate at chest height. 
4. Rotate your body to one side. 
5. Return to the starting position and rotate to the other side.

1. Stand straight holding a dumbbell in each hand with an overhand grip. 
2. Hold the dumbbells in in front of your thighs with your palms of the facing your thighs. 
3. Keep your arms fully extended. 
4. Raise either both dumbbells or one at a time to shoulder height. 
5. Keep your palms facing down. Return to the starting position. 
6. Don’t swing the dumbbells up or let them drop down to the starting position.

1. Stand with your back straight, feet shoulder width apart, while holding a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing inwards. 
2. Keep your elbows close to your sides. 
3. Keeping your arms fully extended and your torsostationary, lift the dumbbells out to your sides and up until they are at shoulder level. 
4. Return to the start position. Don’t swing the weights up with your body or let them fall back to your side.

1. Sit in the rear delt fly machine. Make sure your feet on firmly on the floor. 
2. Lean into the chest pad. 
3. Hold the lever handle and retract your arms and shoulder back so that you are squeezing your shoulder blades together. 
4. Return to the starting position.

1. Stand tall facing a pulley that has been adjusted to higher than head-height. 
2. Attach a rope or dual handles to the pulley and grab hold of each end with your palms facing your head. 
3. Engage your Abs and pull the weight towards your face. 
4. Separate your hands as you pull. 
5. Try to keep your arms parallel to the floor.

1. Sit on a bench that has a back support, holding a dumbbell in each hand with an overhand grip. 
2. Raise the dumbbells to shoulder level, your palms should be facing away from you. 
3. Push the dumbbells up and over your head by extending your arms until the dumbbells touch at the top of the movement. 
4. Slowly return to the start position inhaling as you do so.

1. Grip the bar with an overhand grip, with your hands shoulder width apart and arms fully extended. 
2. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. 
3. Keep your shoulders back. 
4. Raise the bar straight up in one smooth movement, until it is at your upper chest level. 
5. Lower the bar back to the starting position. 
6. Don’t allow the bar to drop down.

1. Place a bench or box behind you just below knee height. 
2. Stand up straight with a tight core and flat back. 
3. Fold your arms in front. 
4. Your feet can be shoulder-width and toes and pointing forward or feet wider and toes pointing outwards. 
5. Slowly descend by driving your hips back first and bending your knees. 
6. Keep your chest up and back straight. 
7. Touch the box with your glutes then slowly rise back to the starting position. 
8. Make sure the bench or box is low enough for your thighs to break parallel.

1. Stand facing the barbell with your shins as close to the bar as possible. 
2. Place your feet shoulder width apart. 
3. Your feet can be pointed straight ahead or turned outwards slightly. 
4. Squat down, keeping your back straight and grip the bar with a double overhand grip or one hand over and one under at shoulder width. 
5. Pull your shoulder blades down.  6. Brace your core and push your weight through your feet as you lift the bar. 
7. As you lift the barbell, your hips and shoulders should rise together and your back should be straight. 
8. Lower the barbell back to the floor keeping the bar as close to your legs as possible.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart while holding a dumbbell to your chest. 
2. You should hold the dumbbell by one end between your hands. 
3. Your feet can be shoulder-width and toes and pointing forward or feet wider and toes pointing outwards. 
4. This is the start position. 
5. Squat down keeping your back straight and pushing your hips back. 
6. Continue down until your thighs are below parallel to the floor. 
7. Hold for a count of one. 
8. Return to the start position. Repeat.

1. Sit on a leg extension machine and place your legs under the pad with your feet pointed forward. 
2. The pad should rest just above your ankles. 
3. You may need to adjust to suit. 
4. Extend your legs until your legs are straight and then return to the starting position. 
5. Do not bounce the weight up.

1. Sit in the leg press machine and place your feet on the platform directly in front of you at shoulder width or wider. 
2. Your feet can be pointing straight ahead or slightly outwards. 
3. Push through your feet on the plate and straighten your legs until your legs are fully extended. 
4. Do not lock your knees out. 
5. Take off the safety bar. 
6. Slowly lower the platform until your hamstring (back of upper leg) touches your calf (back of lower leg). 
7. Push your knees slightly out to the side. 
8. Push the plate back up so your legs are fully extended. 
9. Return to the starting position by pushing through the heels of your feet, engaging your quadriceps. 
10. Lock the safety pin when finished.

1. Stand straight with your feet shoulder width apart and place your hands on your hips or by your side. 
2. This is the start position. Step forward with either leg in a long stride. 
3. Keep your other foot in place behind you. 
4. Bend your knees as you do this so your body is lowered towards the ground. 
5. Keep your back straight throughout the movement. 
6. Continue down until your back knee is just above the ground. (Your front knee be bent at 90 degrees). 
7. Hold for a count of one. 
8. Push down through your front heel and and you toes of your back foot and straighten both knees to return to the start position. 
9. Pause then repeat with your other leg.

1. Lying on your back with either your arms by your side or hands under your glutes. 
2. Place your knees and feet together. 
3. Brace your Abs and raise your legs up to a vertical position. 
4. Lower your legs as low as you can without touching the floor and repeat.

1. Lying oh your back with either your arms by your side or hands under your glutes. 
2. Place your knees and feet together. 
3. Brace your Abs and raise one leg up to a vertical position. 
4. Lower your leg back down as low as you can without touching the floor andat the same time raise the other leg.

1. Set up a cable machine with a rope attachment attached to the top pulley. 
2. Grip the rope with an inverted grip, with your hands close together. 
3. Position your feet shoulder width apart, with knees slightly bent for stability. 
4. Push rope down and pull the rope apart to the side so that your hands finish by your hips at the bottom of the movement.

1. Attach a rope to the top pulley of a cable station. 
2. Grip the rope with both hands using a neutral grip (palms facing inwards). 
3. Turn your body away from the cable station. 
4. Take a split stance and lean forward. 
5. Fully extend your arms straight out over the top of your head pointing straight ahead. 
6. Keep your elbows close to your head. 
7. When your elbows are fully extended, hold for a count of one while squeezing your triceps. 
8. Return to the starting position.

1. Set up a flat bench. 
2. Sit on the bench and position your feet on the floor with your feet behind your knees. 
3. Lie on the bench with an arch in your lower back holding the bar above your chest with your arms extended and elbows locked. 
4. Lower the bar downward towards your forehead in a smooth arc. 
5. Continue lowering the bar until it is just above your forehead and press the bar back over your chest. 
6. You can also use an EZ bar for this exercise.

1. Set up a flat bench. Sit on the bench and position your feet on the floor with your feet behind your knees. 
2. Lie on the bench with an arch in your lower back holding the bar above your chest with your arms extended and elbows locked. 
3. Lower the EZ bar downward towards the back of your head in a smooth arc. 
4. Continue lowering the bar until it is at the height of the back of your head. 
5. Push the bar back above your chest.

1. Grab the bar with your palms facing towards you and a grip that is narrows than shoulder width.
2. Pull yourself up until your head is above the bar. Slowly lower back to the start position.

1. Holding a dumbbell in each hand, stand with your feet shoulder width apart. 
2. Let your arms hang by your side with your palms facing in to the side of your body. 
3. Keep your elbows close to your sides. 
4. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, rotating your forearms. 
5. Do not swing your hips to get the weight moving. 
6. Continue raising the dumbbells until they are level with your shoulders with your palms facing your. 
7. Your forearm should be in a vertical position. 
8. Squeeze or flex your bicep and hold for a count of one. 
9. Slowly lower the dumbbells to the starting position. Repeat.

1. Let a pair of dumbbells hang at arm’s length next to your sides with your palms facing your thighs.
2. Don’t move your arms. Instead, bend your elbows and curl the dumbbells as close to your shoulders as possible.
3. Pause at the top – remember to squeeze – before slowly lowering the weight back to the starting position.

1. With your dumbbells hanging by your side, turn your arms so your palms face forward.
2. Without moving your upper arms, bend your elbows and curl the dumbbells towards your shoulder.
3. Pause, then rotate the dumbbells so your palms face forward before slowly returning back to your starting position.
